avalancheActivity.comment:
The large wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. This applies especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at intermediate and high altitudes.
Avalanches can in some cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size.
In starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and on very steep sunny slopes medium-sized and large natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. This applies in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slabs at high altitude. Moist and wet avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

snowpackStructure.comment: 10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday. The new snow and wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. Faceted weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to rapid moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

avalancheActivity.comment: The sometimes moderate wind has transported the new snow. This snow as well as the wind slabs to be found above the tree line represent the main danger. The wind slabs are quite large can be released easily, especially on very steep slopes at intermediate and high altitudes adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Be careful, many rocks hidden by fresh snow. As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural avalanche activity will gradually increase. This applies in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2200 m, and in steep rocky terrain.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slabs at high altitude. Moist and wet avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

snowpackStructure.comment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

avalancheActivity.comment:
The sometimes moderate wind has transported the new snow significantly. The large wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. This applies especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at intermediate and high altitudes.
Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach large size.
Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.
In starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and on very steep sunny slopes medium-sized and large natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. This applies in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.

Faceted weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to rapid moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

avalancheActivity.comment: The sometimes moderate wind has transported the new snow. This snow as well as the wind slabs to be found above the tree line represent the main danger. The wind slabs are quite large can be released easily, especially on very steep slopes at intermediate and high altitudes adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Be careful, many rocks hidden by fresh snow. As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural avalanche activity will gradually increase. This applies in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2200 m, and in steep rocky terrain.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slabs at high altitude. Moist and wet avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

snowpackStructure.comment:
10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

avalancheActivity.comment:
A lot of new snow at low altitude: The moderate wind has transported the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs can be released, even by a single winter sport participant and reach large size. This applies especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at intermediate and high altitudes, and on steep slopes above the tree line.
In particular on steep shady slopes avalanches can be released in deep layers of the snowpack.
As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural avalanche activity will gradually increase. This applies in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2200 m, and in steep rocky terrain.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience and restraint.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slabs at high altitude. Moist and wet avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

snowpackStructure.comment: 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday. The new snow and wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. Faceted weak layers exist deeper in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from early morning to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
